What are some of the unique capabilities of the Verus PBaaS testnet, and how do they enable new possibilities for decentralized identity management and cryptocurrency usage?

The Verus PBaaS testnet, available as the VRSCTEST coin in the Verus Desktop or cli wallets, offers several capabilities that are unique in the crypto space today. Two notable examples are self-sovereign, revocable, recoverable identities (VerusID) and staking-capable time locking and theft prevention (Verus Vault).

**VerusID:**
VerusID enables users to register friendly name strong identities and funds addresses that are simultaneously fully self-sovereign, revocable, and recoverable. This means that users have complete control over their identities and can revoke or recover them as needed, without relying on a central authority. VerusID is already available on the mainnet.

**Verus Vault:**
Verus Vault is a staking-capable time locking and theft prevention mechanism that allows users to lock their identities, preventing any funds under their control from being spent while locked. This feature enables seamless staking of funds while preventing unauthorized access to the locked identity. Users can specify an unlock delay, which can be used to detect and prevent potential theft. In case of a compromised identity, users can revoke and recover their ID, and even create fresh private keys when unlocking.

These capabilities offer several benefits, including:

* Virtually theft-proof workflows
* Solutions for inheritance, trusts, vesting schedules, and identity theft
* Friendly name cryptocurrency addresses for all currencies on all Verus PBaaS blockchains in the Verus network

Overall, the Verus PBaaS testnet provides a decentralized future with truth and privacy for all, enabling new possibilities for cryptocurrency usage and identity management.

## Staking-capable time locking and theft prevention (Verus Vault)
- Enables identities to be locked, preventing any funds under their control from being spent while locked, but still allowing seamless staking of funds. When locked, a user specifies an unlock delay, typically long enough to notice when someone who might have compromised a user’s keys would have to unlock the ID before spending. The only way to circumvent the unlock delay is to revoke and recover an ID. Users may also choose to create and use fresh private keys when unlocking an ID as well. This enables virtually theft proof workflow and a solution to inheritance, trusts, vesting schedules, the 5$ wrench attack, and identity theft.
